title: Module 12: Building Modern Front-End with React 19
description: Learn React 19's latest features including JSX, components, hooks (useState, useEffect), and the new React 19 hooks
goal: Build interactive, performant user interfaces with React 19's cutting-edge features

lessons.title: JSX - JavaScript Meets HTML (But It's NOT HTML!)
lessons.conceptAnalogy:
Imagine writing a recipe:

Plain text recipe:
- Hard to read
- No structure
- Easy to mess up

Formatted recipe with sections:
- Ingredients (like HTML tags)
- Instructions (like JavaScript logic)
- Combined in one document

JSX is like having ingredients AND instructions in one file:
- Looks like HTML (familiar and readable)
- But it's actually JavaScript (gets compiled)
- Can use JavaScript expressions inside {}

JSX = JavaScript XML. It's JavaScript that LOOKS like HTML!

challenge.instructions:
Practice JSX concepts:

1. Create variables for:
   - `firstName` = your first name
   - `lastName` = your last name
   - `age` = your age

2. Create a `getFullName()` function that returns first + last name

3. Create a simulated JSX structure (as a string) that includes:
   - An h1 with full name
   - A p showing age
   - A p showing if adult (age >= 18)

4. Log the result

Note: Since we're in plain JavaScript, use template literals to simulate JSX.

testCases.input: let first = 'John'; let last = 'Doe'; first + ' ' + last

challenge.hint: Use template literals with ${} to embed JavaScript expressions.

lessons.title: Components and Props (The LEGO Blocks Analogy)
lessons.conceptAnalogy:
Think of React components like LEGO blocks:

Basic LEGO block:
- Standard shape and size
- Can connect to other blocks
- Reusable - use the same piece many times
- Different colors (props) make each one unique

Custom LEGO creation (component):
- Build a car from blocks
- Want 5 cars? Use the same design 5 times
- Each car can be different color (props)
- Change the design once → All cars update

React components are reusable building blocks:
- Define once, use many times
- Pass props to customize each instance
- Compose small components into bigger ones!

challenge.instructions:
Create reusable components with props:

1. Create a `BlogPost` function that takes props:
   - title
   - author
   - content
   - Returns formatted HTML string

2. Create an `AuthorBio` function that takes:
   - name
   - bio
   - Returns formatted HTML string

3. Create a `Blog` function that:
   - Uses BlogPost twice with different data
   - Uses AuthorBio once
   - Returns complete blog page

Test by calling Blog() and logging result.
challenge.hint: Use destructuring in function parameters and template literals for HTML.
